DOC.HEAD: Commerical Titan Launch Tries Again Tonight
DOC.TEXT: Martin Marietta Corp. will try again tonight to conduct the thrice-delayed launch its first commerical Titan 3 rocket with British and Japanese communications satellites. The flight was scrubbed Monday night just five minutes before the planned liftoff when weather balloon data indicated winds 27,000 feet above the launch area were too strong. ``The winds aloft are not acceptable,'' launch commentator Bob Gordon said in announcing the postponement. The launch was rescheduled for 7:20 p.m. tonight. It was postponed twice earlier this month by weather and technical problems. The Titan 3 is to boost into orbit communications satellites for a Japanese company and the British Ministry of Defense. The Japanese Communications Satellite Co. and the British government are sharing the $125 million cost of the rocket and launch services provided by Martin Marietta.
